revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{operational plan | name = Operation Pastorius | partof = the [[American Theater (1939-1945)|American Theater]] of [[World War II]] | image = [[File:Nazi saboteur trial.jpg|325px]] | caption = The third day of the trial of the captured Germans, July 1942. | objective = [[Sabotage]] American economic infrastructure | date = June 1942 | executed_by = Nazi Germany | outcome = Failed }} {{North American Theater}}
'''Operation Pastorius''' was a failed [[Nazi Germany|German]] intelligence plan for [[sabotage]] inside the [[United States]] during [[World War II]]. The operation was staged in June 1942 and was to be directed against strategic American economic targets. The operation was named by [[Admiral]] [[Wilhelm Canaris]], chief of the German ''[[Abwehr]]'', for [[Francis Daniel Pastorius]], the leader of the first organized settlement of Germans in America.
==Background== After the Japanese [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] on December 7, 1941, followed by [[German declaration of war against the United States (1941)|Nazi Germany's declaration of war on the United States]] four days later<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/germany-declares-war-on-the-united-states|title=Germany declares war on the United States - Dec 11, 1941 - HISTORY.com|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2016}}</ref> (and the [[United States declaration of war upon Germany (1941)|United States' declaration of war on Germany]] in response), [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]] authorized a mission to sabotage the American war effort and to make [[Terrorism|terrorist attack]]s on civilian targets to [[Demoralization (warfare)|demoralize]] the American civilian population inside the United States.<ref>{{cite book |title=Shadow Enemies: Hitler's Secret Terrorist Plot Against the United States |author=Alex Abella, Scott Gordon |date=January 2003 |page=17 |publisher=The Lyons Press |isbn=1-5857-4722-X }}</ref> The mission was headed by Admiral [[Wilhelm Canaris]], chief of the German ''Abwehr''. Canaris recalled that during [[World War I]], he organized the sabotage of French installations in Morocco, and entered the United States with other German agents to plant bombs in New York arms factories, including the [[Black Tom explosion|destruction of munitions supplies at Black Tom Island]], in 1916. He hoped that Operation Pastorius would have the same kind of success they had in 1916.<ref>{{cite book |title=Peculiar Liaisons in War, Espionage, and Terrorism of the Twentieth Century |author=John Craig |date=2 February 2004 |page=170 |publisher=Algora Publishing |isbn=0-8758-6331-0 }}</ref>
==Agents== Recruited for Operation Pastorius were eight German residents who had lived in the United States. Two of them, [[Ernst Burger]] and [[Herbert Hans Haupt|Herbert Haupt]], were American citizens. The others, [[George John Dasch]], Edward John Kerling, [[Richard Quirin]], Heinrich Harm Heinck, Hermann Otto Neubauer, and Werner Thiel, had worked at various jobs in the United States. All eight were recruited into the Abwehr [[military intelligence]] organization and were given three weeks of intensive sabotage training in the [[Oberkommando der Wehrmacht|German High Command]] school on an estate at [[Quenzsee|Quenz Lake]], near [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]. The agents were instructed in the manufacture and use of [[Explosive material|explosives]], [[Incendiary device|incendiaries]], [[Blasting cap|primers]], and various forms of mechanical, chemical, and electrical delayed timing devices. Considerable time was spent developing complete background "histories" they were to use in the United States. They were encouraged to converse in English and to read American newspapers and magazines so no suspicion would be aroused if they were interrogated while in the United States.<ref name="Foes">{{cite book |title=Insidious Foes: The Axis Fifth Column and the American Home Front |author=Francis MacDonnell |date=2 November 1995 |page=131 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=0-1950-9268-6 }}</ref>
==Mission== [[File:US Coast Guard station, Amagansett, New York - 20070609 crop.jpg|left|thumb|287px|Amagansett Coast Guard station at Atlantic Avenue Beach in [[Amagansett, New York]]. The station was moved in 1966 to a private residence to protect it from demolition. In May 2007, the structure was moved back to near its original location.]]
Their mission was to stage sabotage attacks on American economic targets: [[hydroelectric plant]]s at [[Niagara Falls]]; the [[Alcoa|Aluminum Company of America]]'s plants in [[Illinois]], [[Tennessee]], and [[New York (state)|New York]]; [[McAlpine Locks and Dam|locks]] on the [[Ohio River]] near [[Louisville, Kentucky]]; the [[Horseshoe Curve (Pennsylvania)|Horseshoe Curve]], a crucial railroad pass near [[Altoona, Pennsylvania]], as well as the [[Pennsylvania Railroad]]'s [[Altoona Works|repair shops]] at Altoona;<ref>[http://www.trainweb.org/horseshoecurve-nrhs/Guide.htm Horseshoe Curve, NRHS - Railfan's Guide to the Altoona Area](Requires Java 1.6 as of 1 January 2009]</ref> a [[cryolite]] plant in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]]; [[Hell Gate Bridge]] in New York; and [[Pennsylvania Station (Newark)|Pennsylvania Station]] in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. The agents were also instructed to spread a wave of terror by planting explosives on [[bridge]]s, [[Train station|railroad station]]s, water facilities, and [[Public space|public places]]. They were given [[counterfeit]] [[birth certificate]]s, [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] Cards, [[Conscription|draft]] deferment cards, nearly $175,000 in American money, and [[driver's license]]s, and put aboard two [[U-boat]]s to land on the east coast of the U.S.<ref name="Foes" />
Before the mission began, it was in danger of being compromised, as George Dasch, head of the team, left sensitive documents behind on a train, and one of the agents when drunk announced to patrons at a bar in [[Paris]] that he was a secret agent.<ref>{{cite book |last= Dobbs |first= Michael |title= Saboteurs: The Nazi Raid on America |publisher= [[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]] |date=February 2004 |isbn= 978-0-375-41470-1}}</ref>
On the night of June 12, 1942, the first submarine to arrive in the U.S., {{GS|U-202||2}},<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uboat.net/boats/u202.htm|title=The Type VIIC boat U-202 - German U-boats of WWII - uboat.net|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2016}}</ref> landed at [[Amagansett, New York]], which is about 100 miles east of [[New York City]], on [[Long Island]], at what today is Atlantic Avenue beach. It was carrying Dasch and three other saboteurs (Burger, Quirin, and Henck). The team came ashore wearing [[Uniforms and insignia of the Kriegsmarine|German Navy uniform]]s so that if they were captured, they would be classified as [[prisoners of war]] rather than [[espionage|spies]].<ref>[http://www.vanderbiltlawreview.org/content/articles/2013/01/Kent_66_Vand_L_Rev_153.pdf Judicial Review for Enemy Fighters: The Court’s Fateful Turn in Ex parte Quirin, the Nazi Saboteur Case] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203001757/http://www.vanderbiltlawreview.org/content/articles/2013/01/Kent_66_Vand_L_Rev_153.pdf |date=3 December 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Battle">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gq-pOED4TSUC&pg=PT98&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=3#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Scorpions: The Battles and Triumphs of FDR's Great Supreme Court Justices |author=Noah Feldman |date=8 November 2010 |page=186 |publisher=[[Hachette Book Group USA]] |isbn=0-4465-8057-0 |accessdate=25 July 2013}}</ref> They also brought their explosives, primers and incendiaries, and buried them along with their uniforms, and put on civilian clothes to begin an expected two-year campaign in the sabotage of American defense-related production.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/libref/historic/famcases/nazi/nazi.htm Federal Bureau of Investigation: George John Dasch and the Nazi Saboteurs], FBI Famous Cases</ref>
When Dasch was discovered amidst the dunes by unarmed [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guardsman]] John C. Cullen, Dasch seized Cullen by the collar, threatened him, and stuffed $260 into Cullen's hand.<ref> Elke Frenzel, [http://www.spiegel.de/international/zeitgeist/0,1518,716753,00.html Hitler's Unfulfilled Dream of a New York in Flames] ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' 16 September 2010</ref> Cullen reported the encounter to his superiors after returning to his station. By the time an armed Coast Guard patrol returned to the site, the Germans, weary from their trans-Atlantic trip, were gone and had taken the [[Long Island Rail Road]] train from the [[Amagansett (LIRR station)|Amagansett station]] into [[Manhattan]], New York City, where they checked in and stayed at a hotel. The Coast Guard then discovered German equipment buried in the beach and reported it to President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] and the [[FBI]]. A massive [[Manhunt (military)|manhunt]] for the German agents was conducted; however, they did not know where exactly the Germans were going.
The other four-member German team headed by Kerling landed without incident at [[Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida]], south of [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] on June 16, 1942. They came on {{GS|U-584||2}}, another submarine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uboat.net/boats/u584.htm|title=The Type VIIC boat U-584 - German U-boats of WWII - uboat.net|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2016}}</ref> This group came ashore wearing [[bathing suit]]s but wore German Navy hats. After landing ashore, they threw away their hats, put on civilian clothes, and started their mission by boarding trains to [[Chicago, Illinois]] and [[Cincinnati, Ohio]].<ref name="Battle" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1372973/Revealed-The-secret-Nazi-operation-Pastorius-land-German-soldiers-U-S-soil-sabotage-war-effort-world-war-two.html |title=Hitler sent German U-boat carrying secret agents to terrorise New York during World War Two (but it got wedged off Long Island) |author=Kevin Dougherty |date=5 April 2011 |publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |accessdate=26 July 2013}}</ref>
The two teams were to meet on July 4th in a hotel in Cincinnati to coordinate their sabotage operations.<ref>Page 130, The Florida Historical Quarterly, Volume 49</ref>
==Mission betrayed== Dasch called Burger into their upper-story hotel room and opened a window, saying they would talk, and if they disagreed, "only one of us will walk out that door—the other will fly out this window." Dasch told him he had no intention of going through with the mission, hated [[Naziism]], and planned to report the plot to the FBI. Burger agreed to defect to the United States immediately.<ref name="McCann2006">{{cite book|author=Joseph T. McCann|title=Terrorism on American Soil: A Concise History of Plots and Perpetrators from the Famous to the Forgotten|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a2p6mqd7xRMC&pg=PA81|year=2006|publisher=Sentient Publications|isbn=978-1-59181-049-0|pages=81–}}</ref><ref name="Dobbs2007">{{cite book|author=Michael Dobbs|title=Saboteurs: The Nazi Raid on America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TWOKF8-fZtAC&pg=PA119|date=18 December 2007|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-307-42755-7|pages=119–}}</ref>
On June 15th, Dasch phoned the New York office of the FBI from a [[Payphone|pay-telephone]] on Manhattan's [[Upper West Side]] explaining who he was and asked to convey the information to [[Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI Director]] [[J. Edgar Hoover]]. When the FBI agent was trying to figure out if he was talking to a [[Crank (person)|crackpot]], Dasch hung up. Four days later, he took a train to [[Washington, D.C.]] and checked in at the [[Mayflower Hotel]]. Dasch walked into FBI headquarters, asked to speak with Director Hoover. He eventually spoke to Assistant Director D.M. Ladd.<ref name="Dobbs2007"/> He finally convinced the FBI by dumping his mission's entire budget of $84,000 on the desk of Assistant Director D. M. Ladd.<ref>{{cite book |title=Helluva Town: The Story of New York City During World War II |author=Richard Goldstein |date=13 April 2010 |page=40 |publisher=[[Free Press (publisher)|Free Press]] |isbn=1-4165-8996-1 }}</ref> At this point, he was taken seriously and interrogated for hours.<ref>[http://www.damninteresting.com/?p=949 Damn Interesting » Operation Pastorius]</ref> Besides Burger, none of the other German agents knew they were betrayed. Over the next two weeks, Burger and the other six were arrested. FBI Chief [[J. Edgar Hoover]] made no mention that Dasch had turned himself in, and claimed credit for the FBI for cracking the spy ring.<ref name="wapomonument" />
==Mugshots== <gallery class="center" heights="175px" mode="packed"> File:George John Dasch.jpg|[[George John Dasch]] File:Ernest Peter Burger.jpg|[[Ernst Peter Burger]] File:Herbert Haupt - mugshot.jpg|[[Herbert Hans Haupt|Herbert Haupt]] File:Heinrich Heinck - mugshot.jpg|[[Heinrich Heinck]] File:Edward John Kerling - mugshot.jpg|[[Eddie Kerling]] File:Herman Otto Neubauer.jpg|[[Herman Otto Neubauer]] File:Richard Quirin - mugshot.jpg|[[Richard Quirin]] File:Werner Thiel - mugshot.jpg|[[Werner Thiel]] </gallery>
==Trial and execution== Fearful that a civilian court would be too lenient, President Roosevelt issued Executive Proclamation 2561 on 2 July 1942 creating a [[military tribunal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=16281|title=Franklin D. Roosevelt: Proclamation 2561—Denying Certain Enemies Access to the Courts|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2016}}</ref> to prosecute the Germans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2010-07-12/story/agents-picked-ponte-vedra-landing-point-1942 |title=A Look Back: Nazi agents picked Ponte Vedra as landing point in 1942 |author=Jessie-Lynne Kerr |date=12 July 2010 |work=[[The Florida Times-Union]]}}</ref> Placed before a seven-member military commission, the Germans were charged with the following offenses:
:* 1) Violating the [[law of war]]; :* 2) Violating Article 81 of the [[Articles of War#United States of America|Articles of War]], defining the offense of corresponding with or giving intelligence to the enemy; :* 3) Violating Article 82 of the Articles of War, defining the offense of spying; and :* 4) Conspiracy to commit the offenses alleged in the first three charges.
The trial was held in Assembly Hall #1 on the fifth floor of the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] building in Washington D.C. on 8 July 1942.<ref>{{cite book|title=Roosevelt's Secret War: FDR and World War II Espionage |author=Joseph E. Persico |page=204 | publisher=[[Random House]]| date=22 October 2002 | isbn=0-3757-6126-8}}</ref> Lawyers for the accused, who included [[Lauson Stone]] and [[Kenneth Royall]], attempted to have the case tried in a civilian court but were rebuffed by the [[United States Supreme Court]] in ''[[Ex parte Quirin]]'', 317 U.S. 1 (1942), a case that was later cited as a precedent for the trial by military commission of any [[unlawful combatant]] against the United States.
The trial for the eight defendants ended on 1 August 1942. Two days later, all were found guilty and sentenced to death. Roosevelt commuted Burger's sentence to life in prison and Dasch's to 30 years because they had turned themselves in and provided information about the others. The others were executed on 8 August 1942 in the [[electric chair]] on the third floor of the District of Columbia jail and buried in a [[potter's field]] in the [[Blue Plains (Washington, D.C.)|Blue Plains]] neighborhood in the [[Anacostia]] area of Washington.
==Aftermath== The failure of Operation Pastorius led Hitler to rebuke Admiral Canaris and no sabotage attempt was ever made again in the United States. During the remaining years of the war, the Germans only once more dispatched agents to the United States by submarine. In November 1944, as part of [[Operation Elster]] a German submarine, [[German submarine U-1230|U-1230]], dropped two [[SS-Reichssicherheitshauptamt|RSHA]] spies off the coast of [[Maine]] to gather intelligence on American manufacturing and technical progress. The FBI captured both men shortly after.<ref name="Miller2013">{{cite book|author=Robert A. Miller|title=A True Story of An American Nazi Spy: William Curtis Colepaugh|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ndSkplZUUh8C&pg=PA73&dq=%22There+is+not+one+word+of+reference+to+sabotaging+the+atom+bomb%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwifjZb-wJrVAhWDgj4KHXZ9CXcQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=%22There%20is%20not%20one%20word%20of%20reference%20to%20sabotaging%20the%20atom%20bomb%22&f=false|date=27 February 2013|publisher=Trafford Publishing|isbn=978-1-4669-8219-2|pages=73–}}</ref> These agents benefited from the calmer state of public nerves in the later years of the war and received prison sentences rather than execution.<ref>{{cite book |title=Insidious Foes: The Axis Fifth Column and the American Home Front |author=Francis MacDonnell |date=2 November 1995 |page=133 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=0-1950-9268-6 }}</ref>
In 1948, President [[Harry S. Truman]] granted executive clemency to Dasch and Burger on the condition that they be deported to the [[American Zone of Occupation#American Zone of Occupation|American Zone of occupied Germany]]. They were not welcomed back in Germany, as they were regarded as traitors who had caused the death of their comrades.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Shoot or hang themselves? |url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-7859070.html|newspaper=Der Spiegel|number=15|language=German|date=6 April 1998}}</ref> Although they had been promised pardons by Hoover in exchange for their cooperation, both men died without ever receiving them. Dasch died in 1992 at the age of 89 in [[Ludwigshafen]], [[Germany]]. Burger died in 1975.
Sometime in the 1960s or 1970s, the [[National Socialist White People's Party]] placed an unauthorized monument to the executed spies in a thicket in southwest Washington, D.C. on National Park Service land. It went largely unknown and ignored for several decades; the Park Service removed the monument in 2010.<ref name="wapomonument">{{cite news |last=Cox |first=John Woodrow |date=June 23, 2017 |title=Six Nazi spies were executed in D.C. White supremacists gave them a memorial — on federal land. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/06/23/six-nazi-spies-were-executed-in-d-c-white-supremacists-gave-them-a-memorial-on-federal-land/ |work=The Washington Post |access-date=June 23, 2017 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Duquesne Spy Ring]] *''[[They Came to Blow Up America]]'', a 1943 film based on Operation Pastorius, starring [[George Sanders]] *''[[Saboteur (film)|Saboteur]]'', a 1942 film revolving around acts of sabotage on the US mainland during World War II. *[[New York at War]], military parade held at same time
==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}}
;Bibliography {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= | video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?181143-1/saboteurs-nazi-raid-america ''Booknotes'' interview with Michael Dobbs on ''Saboteurs: The Nazi Raid on America'', 28 March 2004], [[C-SPAN]]}} *Dobbs, Michael, ''Saboteurs: The Nazi Raid on America,'' New York: Knopf, 2004. {{ISBN|0-375-41470-3}} *Rachlis, Eugene, ''They Came to Kill: The Story of Eight Nazi Saboteurs in America'', New York: Random House, 1961. *[[Joseph E. Persico|Persico, Joseph E.]], ''Roosevelt's Secret War: FDR and World War II Espionage'', New York:Random House, 2001, pp. 199–205. {{ISBN|0-375-50246-7}} *[https://www.fbi.gov/libref/historic/famcases/nazi/nazi.htm Federal Bureau of Investigation: George John Dasch and the Nazi Saboteurs] *[http://www.usswashington.com/dl10ju42.htm Lippmann, David H., ''World War II Plus 55, June 10-13th, 1942''] *[http://www.montauklife.com/history/history_night_of_the_nazis.html Montauk Life: The Night of the Nazis] *[https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0317_0001_ZS.html Cornell University School of Law: ''Ex Parte Quirin'' (summary)] *Samaha, Joel, ''et al.'' (eds.), ''Transcript of Proceedings before the Military Commission to Try Persons Charged with Offenses against the Law of War and the Articles of War, Washington D.C., 8 to 31 July 1942'', Minneapolis: University of Minnesota, 2004. [http://www.soc.umn.edu/~samaha/nazi_saboteurs/indexnazi.htm] *Abella, Alex & Gordon, Scott, ''Shadow Enemies: Hitler's Secret Terrorist Plot Against the United States'', Guilford, CT: Lyons Press, 2002. {{ISBN|1-58574-722-X}}
'''Further information''' *[http://www.thisamericanlife.org/Radio_Episode.aspx?sched=1019 The Facts Don't Matter] An hour-long ''This American Life'' radio episode (original air date 3/12/2004) about the events leading up to ''Ex parte Quirin''
==External links== {{commons category|Operation Pastorius}} *[http://ghostsofdc.org/2012/02/09/six-nazi-saboteurs-executed-in-washington/ Six Nazi Saboteurs Executed in Washington] - Ghosts of DC history blog *{{IMDb title|id=0036426 |title= They Came to Blow Up America}} - a 1943 film about saboteurs, led by a German-American, landing on Long Island *{{cite newspaper |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/03/nyregion/john-cullen-coast-guardsman-who-detected-spies-dies-at-90.html |title= John Cullen, Coast Guardsman Who Detected Spies, Dies at 90 |author= Richard Goldstein |date= September 2, 2011 |work= The New York Times}}

The '''Provincial Assembly of the City-province of Kinshasa''' (French, ''l’Assemblée provinciale de la ville-province de Kinshasa'') is the legislative body of the City-province of [[Kinshasa]]. [[Roger Nsingi Mbemba]] is the speaker of the provincial assembly.
[[Category:Kinshasa]] [[Category:Provincial legislatures of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] {{DRCongo-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Singapore English|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox Network | name = Radio Singapore International (RSI) | logo = [[File:Radio Singapore International logo.png]] | country = [[Singapore]] | network_type = [[Radio network]] | available = International | owner = [[Radio Corporation of Singapore]] (RCS)
[[MediaCorp Radio]] | groups = [[MediaCorp|Singapore International Media]] (SIM)
[[MediaCorp]] | founded = 1 January 1994 as '''Radio Corporation of Singapore''' ('''RCS''')
1 January 2002 as '''MediaCorp Radio''' | slogan = '''Voice of Singapore'''
'''Suara Singapura'''
'''新加坡之声''' | motto = '''Voice of Singapore'''
'''Suara Singapura'''
'''新加坡之声''' | license_area = Caldecott Broadcasting Centre | broadcast_area = International | area = [[Singapore]] | key_people = '''Ho Kwon Ping''' | airdate = 1 January 1994 as '''Radio Corporation of Singapore''' ('''RCS''')
1 January 2002 as '''MediaCorp Radio''' | launch_date = 1 January 1994 as '''Radio Corporation of Singapore''' ('''RCS''')
1 January 2002 as '''MediaCorp Radio''' | closure_date = 31 December 2007 | language = [[English language|English]] | past_names = |}} '''Radio Singapore International''' ([[abbreviation|abbrev]]: '''RSI'''; [[Simplified Chinese|Chinese]]: 新加坡国际广播电台 [[Pinyin]]: Xīnjiāpō Guójì Guǎngbō Diàntái; {{lang-ms|Radio Internasional Singapura}}) was the official [[international broadcasting]] station of [[Singapore]] and the largest radio international broadcasting company in Singapore existing from 1 January 1994 to 31 December 2001. The predecessor of '''[[MediaCorp Radio]]''' successor of the radio broadcasting arm of the '''[[Singapore Broadcasting Corporation]]''' ('''SBC''') was privatised on 1 January 1994 at 00:00 am ([[UTC+8]]) in conjunction with New Year's Day 1994 at midnight into three individual companies, one of which was TCS and RCS. RCS subsequently went through a group restructure under the '''[[MediaCorp|SIM Group of Companies]]''' based parent by '''[[MediaCorp|Singapore International Media]]''' ('''SIM''') on 1 January 2002 and became '''MediaCorp Radio'''. '''Radio Singapore International''' ('''RSI''') was a [[shortwave radio]] station that broadcast out of Singapore. The station which was run by ''''[[Radio Corporation of Singapore]]''' ('''RCS''') now '''MediaCorp Radio''' broadcast in [[English language|English]], [[Cantonese]], [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Malay language|Malay]] and [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]]. The English service operated on shortwave between 1100hrs - 1400hrs UTC daily on 6080 kHz and 6150 kHz (49m Band). A "'''Live'''" audio stream was also available on its website. Its signal was carried "'''Live'''" for an hour daily on Singapore's main English news station '''[[938LIVE]]''' (FM 93.8 MHz). RSI's news and [[current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] programming cover [[finance|financial]], [[economics|economic]], and [[politics|political]] developments around the world, but primarily around [[Southeast Asia]]. RSI's lifestyle programmes cover a variety of areas, from [[culture]] and [[travel]] to the [[Internet]] and [[technology]]. Music played on the station ranges from classic and oldies, to contemporary and easy listening. Sakuntala Gupta was Senior Programme Director of RSI (English). Past producers/presenters of RSI's English service were: Bharati Jagdish, who now co-anchors a morning show on '''MediaCorp Radio 938 LIVE''', Ariel Wee, Chan Kah Mei, Daphne Tan, Howie Lim, Belinda Sunshine, Augustine Anthuvan, Felix Tan, Melanie Yip, Loretta Foo, Michael Darren Tan, Jason Tan and Shereena Sajeed. Past contributors of RSI were: William Xavier, [[Janadas Devan]], Chris Ho, and Mike Kellerman. On 1 January 2005, RSI (English) also launched a microsite which features articles covering a range of issues related to travel, entertainment and controversial socio-political issues. == Notable Former RSI Crews (Malay Service) == Inon Salleh - most recently a Malay news editor for Radio
Roslinda Rahmat - most recently a Malay news editor for TV
Ibrahim Sawifi - most recently a Malay news editor for TV
Illydea Ishak - most recently an understudy for Warna 94.2fm
Saifulbahri Ismail - most recently an English news editor for TV
Haslinda Ali
Norshima Aziz - most recently a Malay news editor for Radio
Faridah Hassan (Freda) - most recently a RIA 89.7fm DJ
Zawiyah Majid (Zaza)- most recently a Warna 94.2fm DJ
== Former RSI Crews (Indonesian Service) == Tjandra Mualim - passed away in 2015
Harry Suhartanto - passed away in 2013
Budi Setiawan - residing in Jakarta
Fransiska Beding - now lives in Macau
Eva Mazrieva - currently Producer at Voice of America in Washington
Rane Hafied - currently works for an agency in Bangkok
Ni Wayan Suryatini - currently works at Metro TV Jakarta
Monang Harahap - currently works in Jakarta
Entin Supriati - currently works in Depok, West Java
Vina Mubtadi - currently works as Producer at Voice of America in Washington
Aji Rokhadi - currently works at Radio Japan, NHK World, Tokyo
== Closure == On 1 November 2007, MediaCorp announced that RSI would end its transmission on 31 December 2007. MediaCorp said "'''The effectiveness of a shortwave radio service has diminished over time, with changing technology and media consumption habits'''", thus "'''It is no longer optimal to continue with a full regional radio service'''". == See also == * [[MediaCorp Radio]], Singapore's publicly funded radio broadcaster == References == {{reflist}} {{Radio stations in Singapore}} {{MediaCorp}} {{coord missing|Singapore}} [[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Radio stations in Singapore]] [[Category:Broadcasting in Singapore]] [[Category:Mediacorp]] [[Category:Companies of Singapore]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Singapore]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1994]]

The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Goré''' ({{lang-la|Goren(sis)}}) is a [[diocese]] in [[Goré]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Archdiocese of N'Djamena|N'Djamena]] in [[Chad]].
==History== * November 28, 1998: Established as Diocese of Goré from the [[Diocese of Doba]] and [[Diocese of Moundou]]
==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Goré (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Rosario Pio Ramolo]], [[O.F.M. Cap.]] (since November 28, 1998)
==See also== [[Roman Catholicism in Chad]]
==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/gore0.htm GCatholic.org]

The '''Territorial Prelature of Infanta''' ({{lang-la|Praelatura Territorialis Infantensis}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] [[territorial prelature]] located in the municipality of [[Infanta, Quezon]], in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lipa|Lipa]] in the Philippines.
==Prelates== [[File:GNakarChurchjf0228_27.JPG|thumb|Map of the Prelature]]
*'''Patrick Harmon Shanley, OCD†''': July 11, 1951 - September 12, 1960 *'''[[Julio Xavier Labayen]], OCD†''': June 23, 1961 - June 28, 2003 *'''[[Rolando Tirona|Rolando Octavus Joven Tria Tirona]]''': June 28, 2003 - September 8, 2012 *'''Bernardino Cruz Cortez''': October 27, 2014 - present
==Vicariates==
===Vicariate of Infant Jesus and St. Mark (RIN-Llavac)=== *'''Cathedral-Parish of the Divine Infant Jesus of Prague and St. Mark the Evangelist''' - [[Infanta, Quezon|Infanta]] *'''St. Raphael the Archangel Parish''' - [[Real, Quezon|Real]] *'''St. Joseph, Husband of Mary Quasi-Parish''' - Llavac, Real *'''Sts. Joachim and Anne Parish''' - [[General Nakar, Quezon|Gen. Nakar]]

===Vicariate of St. Louis Bishop (Valley-Ding)=== *'''St. Louis Bishop Parish''' - [[Baler]] *'''St. Vincent Ferrer Parish''' - [[Maria Aurora, Aurora|Ma. Aurora]] *'''Maria, Ina ng Sambayanan ng mga Dukha Parish''' - Quirino, Ma. Aurora *'''St. Louis King Parish''' - [[San Luis, Aurora|San Luis]] *'''St. Therese of the Child Jesus Parish''' - [[Dipaculao]] *'''St. Patrick Parish''' - [[Dingalan]]
===Vicariate of St. Anthony de Padua (DiBiCaDi)=== *'''St. Anthony de Padua Parish''' - [[Casiguran, Aurora|Casiguran]] *'''Nuestra Señora de Salvacion Parish''' - Bianoan, Casiguran *'''St. Isidore the Farmer Parish''' - [[Dinalungan]] *'''St. Joseph the Worker Parish''' - [[Dilasag]]

page.title: The Arctic Institute – Center for Circumpolar Security Studies

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = The Arctic Institute - Center for Circumpolar Security Studies | image = | abbreviation = TAI | motto = Collaboration. Creativity. Independence. | formation = 2011 | type = [[Public policy]]-[[Think tank]] | headquarters = [[Washington D.C.]] | leader_title = Managing Director | leader_name = Victoria Herrmann | website = {{URL|www.thearcticinstitute.org}} }}
The Arctic Institute (TAI) is an independent, [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] [[Arctic cooperation and politics|Arctic policy]] and research organization based in [[Washington, D.C.]] Founded in 2011, TAI’s stated goals include providing data, analysis, and recommendations to policymakers, researchers, and the public about Arctic environmental, human, and national security challenges. TAI is international in scope, with field-based researchers from several circumpolar countries including [[Canada]], [[Norway]], [[Denmark]] and the [[US]].
== History == TAI was established in 2011 by Malte Humpert. Inspired by the 2006 documentary [[An Inconvenient Truth|An Inconvenient Truth]], the writings of polar historian [[Charles Emmerson]], and polar scientist [[Alun Anderson]], Humpert created TAI in order to provide a platform for developing informed policy to respond to the rapid changes underway in the Arctic region. In 2016, TAI was shortlisted by Prospect Magazine’s [[Think Tank]] Awards for best Energy and Environment Think Tank in the United States.<ref name="Prospect"/> In 2015 and 2016, TAI was ranked 61 of 1,835 in Top Think Tanks in the United States by the [[University of Pennsylvania]] Global Go To Think Tank Index Report.<ref name="Global"/>
== Activities == TAI is involved in 10 areas of Arctic policy research: * [[Natural resources of the Arctic|Business and Economics]] * [[Climate of the Arctic|Climate Change]] and [[Save the Arctic|Environment]] <ref name="NYT"/> * [[Circumpolar peoples|Indigenous Rights]] and [[Poverty in the Arctic|Society]] * [[Arctic Ocean Conference|Law]] and [[Arctic Council|Governance]] * [[Natural resources of the Arctic|Natural Resources]] and [[Petroleum exploration in the Arctic|Energy]] * [[Territorial claims in the Arctic|Politics]] and [[Arctic cooperation and politics|Strategy]] * [[Arctic shipping routes|Shipping]] and [[Arctic Bridge|Trade]] <ref name="Economist"/> * Youth and [[University of the Arctic|Education]]
TAI regularly publishes reports on [[Global warming in the Arctic|climate change]], [[diplomacy]], and security developments in the region. The Arctic This Week (TATW) is a [[newsletter]] which was started in 2012.<ref name="TATW" https://www.thearcticinstitute.org/the-arctic-this-week/ />
== Collaborations == TAI works with a variety of [[non-governmental organizations]], [[universities]], international, national, and sub-national government agencies, and individual researchers. Among these are: <ref name="Collaboration" /> * The [[Pacific Northwest Economic Region]], * the [[Centre for High North Logistics|High North Center]] of the [[University of Nordland]] ([[Norway]]), * [[UK]] Science and Innovation Nordics Network, * the [[Arctic Circle (organization)|Arctic Circle Assembly]], * the Arctic Adaptation Exchange of the [[Arctic Council]].
== Organization ==
TAI is led by a Leadership Team of [[Fellow|Senior Fellows]] together with the [[Board of Directors]] and distinguished [[Advisory board|Board of Advisers]].<ref name="Advisors"/>
The Board of Directors is led by David Slayton, [[Executive Director]] of the [https://www.hoover.org/research-teams/arctic-security-working-group Arctic Security Initiative] at Stanford University's Hoover Institution. The Board’s role is to provide governance of financial affairs, guide the selection of research projects, and safeguard the independence of the Institute’s work.<ref name="Directors"/>
== Board of Advisers ==
TAI’s [[Advisory board|Board of Advisers]] is composed of figures in the Arctic research and policymaking community.
* Senior [[Climate Change]] Advisor to [[GRID-Arendal]] Polar Center John Crump, * [[Royal Holloway]] Professor Klaus Dodds, * [[Executive Director]] of the [[United States Arctic Research Commission|US Arctic Research Commission]] John Farrell, * [[Advisor|Special Advisor]] and Chief Negotiator of the [[Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami]] Udloriak Hanson, * [[University of Lapland]] Professor Lassi Heininen, * Founder of Ecologic Institute Andreas Kraemer, * Dean of the [[Norwegian Institute for Defence Studies|Norwegian Defence University College]] Kristine Offerdal, * Former [[Ambassador of Iceland to the United Kingdom|Icelandic Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] Thordur Aegir Oskarsson, * [[Norwegian Institute for Defence Studies]] Professor Rolf Tamnes.
== External Links == * [http://www.thearcticinstitute.org/ Website of The Arctic Institute] * [https://www.theguardian.com/profile/victoria-herrmann Articles of Victoria Herrmann in [[The Guardian]]] * [https://savingplaces.org/americas-eroding-edges#.WliDIktG2i4 Americas Eroding Edges] {{Commonscat|The Arctic Institute}}
== References == {{reflist|refs= <ref name="Prospect">Think Tank Awards 2017. Who won? [https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/magazine/think-tank-awards-2017-who-won]</ref> <ref name="Global">Global Go To Think Tank Index Report [https://repository.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1009&context=think_tanks]</ref> <ref name="TATW">The Arctic This Week [https://www.thearcticinstitute.org/the-arctic-this-week/]</ref> <ref name="Collaboration"> 2016 Annual Report. Collaborations [https://www.thearcticinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/TAI-2016-Annual-Report.pdf?x62767]</ref> <ref name="Advisors">Board of Advisors [https://www.thearcticinstitute.org/board-of-advisors/]</ref> <ref name="Directors">Board of Directors [https://www.thearcticinstitute.org/board-of-directors/]</ref> <ref name="NYT">Reeling From Effects of Climate Change, Alaskan Village Votes to Relocate [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/20/us/shishmaref-alaska-elocate-vote-climate-change.html?_r=0/]</ref> <ref name="Economist">Snow dragons [http://www.economist.com/node/21561891/]</ref> }}

[[Antarctica]] showing USAP field research sites and research vessels | footnotes = {{cite web |url=https://www.nsf.gov/geo/plr/antarct/treaty/opp10001/big_print_0910/big_print_0910.pdf |title=2009-2010 Season Summary and Background |work=USAP |publisher=[[National Science Foundation]] |date=January 8, 2010 |accessdate=July 11, 2016 |page=24}} | embed = }} The '''United States Antarctic Program''' (or '''USAP'''; formerly known as the '''United States Antarctic Research Program''' or '''USARP''' and the '''United States Antarctic Service''' or '''USAS''') is an organization of the [[United States]] government which has presence in the [[continent]] of [[Antarctica]]. Founded in 1959, the USAP manages all U.S. scientific research and related logistics in Antarctica as well as aboard ships in the [[Southern Ocean]]. The body's goals are:{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/pubs/2008/nsf08535/nsf08535.htm|title=Antarctic Research nsf08535|date=January 16, 2008|publisher=National Science Foundation|accessdate=5 September 2010}}
...to understand the Antarctic and its associated [[ecosystems]]; to understand the region's effects on, and responses to, global processes such as climate; and to use Antarctica's unique features for scientific research that cannot be done as well elsewhere.
==Programs and services== [[File:UnitedStatesAntarcticProgramChristchurch01 gobeirne.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III]] servicing the United States Antarctic Program at Christchurch International Airport, Christchurch, New Zealand.]] The U.S. Antarctic Program, funded by the [[National Science Foundation]]'s Office of Polar Programs, supports only research that can be done exclusively in Antarctica or that can be done best from Antarctica. The scientific disciplines encompassed by the USAP are astronomy, atmospheric sciences, biology, earth science, environmental science, geology, glaciology, marine biology, oceanography, and geophysics. Currently, the USAP maintains three year-round research stations in Antarctica, the [[McMurdo Station]], the [[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]], and the [[Palmer Station]]. In addition, the USAP operates several summer research camps and several research vessels that sail in the Antarctic waters.{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/od/opp/antarct/usap.jsp|title=United States Antarctic Program|accessdate=5 September 2010}} The program's fiscal budget for 2008 was {{USD}}295 million,{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=102869|title=U.S. Antarctic Program|date=December 29, 2008|work=Fact Sheet|publisher=The National Science Foundation|accessdate=5 September 2010}} and for 2012 was {{USD}}350 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=102869|title=U.S. Antarctic Program|date=January 10, 2013|work=Fact Sheet|publisher=The National Science Foundation|accessdate=8 February 2015}} ==See also== *[[The Antarctic Sun]] *[[Operation Deep Freeze]] *[[USNS Eltanin (T-AK-270)|''Eltanin'']] *[[Antarctic ecosystem]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|United States Antarctic Program}} * {{official website|http://www.usap.gov/}} * [http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/ The Antarctic Sun] {{portalbar|Antarctica|United States|Government}} {{Antarctica}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:United States Antarctic Program| ]] [[Category:Antarctic agencies]] {{US-gov-stub}}
